1 .

If x∈R and x<y+ϵ for every ϵ>0, prove that x≤y.  

Ans: Suppose on contrary that x>y. Take ϵ=x−y>0. By hypothesis,  

x<y+ϵ  

⇒x<y+(x−y)  

⇒x<x  

⇒1<1  

This is a contradiction. Hence x≤y.  

2 .

If x∈R and x≤y+ϵ for every ϵ>0, prove that x≤y.  

Ans: Suppose on contrary that x>y. Take ϵ=x−y2>0. By hypothesis,  

x<y+ϵ  

⇒x<y+x−y2  

⇒x−y<x−y2  

⇒1<12  

This is a contradiction. Hence x≤y.  

Archimedian Property of Real Numbers: For any real number x, there is a positive integer N such that N>x.

3 .

Prove that limn→∞1n=0.  

Ans: Let ϵ>0. By Archimedian property of real numbers, there is N∈I such that

N>1ϵ

Consider  

n≥N  

⇒n>1ϵ  

⇒1ϵ<n  

⇒1n<ϵ  

⇒∣∣1n−0∣∣<ϵ  

Thus for N>1ϵ,  

n≥N⇒∣∣1n−0∣∣<ϵ  

This proves that limn→∞1n=0  

4 .

Prove that limn→∞1n+3=0.  

Ans: Let ϵ>0. By Archimedian property of real numbers, there is N∈I such that

N>1ϵ

Consider  

n≥N  

⇒n>1ϵ  

⇒1ϵ<n  

⇒1n<ϵ  

⇒1n+3<ϵ    (∵1n+3<1n)  

⇒∣∣1n+3−0∣∣<ϵ  

Thus for N>1ϵ,  

n≥N⇒∣∣1n+3−0∣∣<ϵ  

This proves that limn→∞1n+3=0  

5 .

Prove that limn→∞1n−3=0.  

Ans: Let ϵ>0. By Archimedian property of real numbers, there is N(≥3)∈I such that

N>1ϵ+3

Consider  

n≥N  

⇒n>1ϵ+3  

⇒1ϵ+3<n  

⇒1ϵ<n−3  

⇒1n−3<ϵ  

⇒∣∣1n−3−0∣∣<ϵ  

Thus for N>1ϵ+3,  

n≥N⇒∣∣1n−3−0∣∣<ϵ  

This proves that limn→∞1n−3=0  

6 .

Prove that limn→∞205n=0.  

Ans: Let ϵ>0. By Archimedian property of real numbers, there is N∈I such that

N>205ϵ

Consider  

n≥N  

⇒n>205ϵ  

⇒205ϵ<n  

⇒205n<ϵ  

⇒∣∣205n−0∣∣<ϵ  

Thus for N>205ϵ,  

n≥N⇒∣∣205n−0∣∣<ϵ  

This proves that limn→∞205n=0  

7 .

Show that the sequence {sn}∞n=1={n}∞n=1 is divergent.  

Ans: Suppose on contrary that {sn}∞n=1={n}∞n=1 is convergent and let limn→∞sn=L. Then for ϵ=1>0, there is N∈I such that  

n≥N⇒|sn−L|<1  

⇒(n≥N⇒|n−L|<1)  

⇒(n≥N⇒L−1<n<L+1) 

⇒L−1<N,N+2<L+1  

⇒(N+2)−N<(L+1)−(L−1) 

⇒2<2 

This is a contradiction. Hence {sn}∞n=1={n}∞n=1 is divergent.  

8 .

Show that the sequence {sn}∞n=1={(−1)n}∞n=1 is divergent.  

Ans: Suppose on contrary that {sn}∞n=1={(−1)n}∞n=1 is convergent and let limn→∞sn=L. Then for ϵ=1>0, there is N∈I such that  

n≥N⇒|sn−L|<1  

⇒(n≥N⇒∣∣(−1)n−L∣∣<1)  

⇒(n≥N⇒L−1<(−1)n<L+1) 

⇒L−1<(−1)2N+1,(−1)2N<L+1  

⇒L−1<−1,1<L+1  

⇒1−(−1)<(L+1)−(L−1) 

⇒2<2 

This is a contradiction. Hence {sn}∞n=1={(−1)n}∞n=1 is divergent.  

9 .

If {sn}∞n=1 is a sequence of real numbers and if for every ϵ>0 ,

n≥N⇒|sn−L|<ϵ

where N does not depend on ϵ, prove that all terms except first N−1 terms of {sn}∞n=1 are equal to L.  

Ans: We shall use the following result  

“If x∈R and x≤y+ϵ for every ϵ>0 then x≤y.” …(∗)  

Consider  

n≥N⇒|sn−L|<ϵ for every ϵ>0  

⇒(n≥N⇒L−ϵ<sn<L+ϵ for every ϵ>0)  

⇒(n≥N⇒L<sn+ϵ and sn<L+ϵ for every ϵ>0)  

⇒(n≥N⇒L≤sn and sn≤L)    (by (*))  

⇒(n≥N⇒sn=L)  

⇒sN=sN+1=sN+2=⋯=L  

⇒ all terms except first N−1 terms of {sn}∞n=1 are equal to L.  

10 .

(a) Find a positive integer N such that

n≥N⇒∣∣2nn+3−2∣∣<15

(b) Prove that limn→∞2nn+3=2  

Ans: (a) : Take N=31. Consider  

n≥N  

⇒n≥31  

⇒n>30  

⇒30<n  

⇒6n<15  

⇒6n+3<15    (∵6n+3<6n )  

⇒∣∣2nn+3−2∣∣<15  

Thus for N=30  

n≥N⇒∣∣2nn+3−2∣∣<15  

(b) Let ϵ>0. By Archimedian property of real numbers, there is N∈I such that

N>6ϵ

Consider  

n≥N  

⇒n>6ϵ  

⇒6ϵ<n  

⇒6n<ϵ  

⇒6n+3<ϵ    (∵6n+3<6n )  

⇒∣∣2nn+3−2∣∣<ϵ  

Thus for N>1ϵ,  

n≥N⇒∣∣2nn+3−2∣∣<ϵ  

This proves that limn→∞2nn+3=2  

 

11 .

(a) Find a positive integer N such that

n≥N⇒1√n+1<0.03

(b) Prove that limn→∞1√n+1=0  

Ans: (a) By Archimedian property of real numbers, there is N∈I such that

N>100009

Consider  

n≥N  

⇒n>100009  

⇒100009<n  

⇒1n<910000  

⇒1n+1<910000    (∵1n+1<1n )  

⇒1√n+1<3100  

⇒1√n+1<0.03  

Thus for N>100009  

n≥N⇒1√n+1<0.03  

(b) By Archimedian property of real numbers, there is N∈I such that

N>1ϵ2

Consider  

n≥N  

⇒n>1ϵ2  

⇒1ϵ2<n  

⇒1n<ϵ2  

⇒1n+1<ϵ2    (∵1n+1<1n )  

⇒1√n+1<ϵ  

⇒1√n+1<ϵ  

⇒∣∣∣1√n+1−0∣∣∣<ϵ  

Thus for N>1ϵ2  

n≥N⇒∣∣∣1√n+1−0∣∣∣<ϵ  

This proves that limn→∞1√n+1=0.  

12 .

Let {sn}∞n=1 be a sequence of positive numbers and 0<x<1. If sn+1<xsn for all n∈I, prove that limn→∞sn=0.  

Ans: 0<x<1  

⇒0<xsn<sn     (∵sn>0)  

⇒0<sn+1<sn     (∵sn+1<xsn)  

Thus the sequence {sn}∞n=1 is non-increasing and bounded below by 0. So it is convergent. Take limn→∞sn=L. Consider  

0<sn+1<xsn  

⇒0<sn+1−xsn<0 

⇒0≤limn→∞(sn+1−xsn)≤0 

⇒limn→∞(sn+1−xsn)=0  

⇒limn→∞sn+1−xlimn→∞sn=0  

⇒L−xL=0     (∵limn→∞sn+1=L as {sn+1}∞n=1 is a subsequence of {sn}∞n=1)  

⇒(1−x)L=0  

⇒L=0     (∵x−1≠0 as x≠1)  

13 .

If limn→∞sn−1sn+1=0 then show that limn→∞sn=1.  

Ans: Take ϵn=sn−1sn+1. Then  

⇒ϵn(sn+1)=sn−1  

⇒1+ϵn=sn(1−ϵn)  

⇒sn=1+ϵn1−ϵn  

⇒limn→∞sn=limn→∞1+ϵn1−ϵn 

⇒limn→∞sn=1+limn→∞ϵn1−limn→∞ϵn  

⇒limn→∞sn=1+01−0        (∵limn→∞ϵn=limn→∞sn−1sn+1=0) 

⇒limn→∞sn=1  

14 .

If sn=10nn!, find a positive integer N such that n≥N⇒sn+1<sn.  

Ans: Take N=10. Consider  

n≥N  

⇒n>9  

⇒10<n+1  

⇒10n+110n<(n+1)!n! 

⇒10n+1(n+1)!<10nn!  

⇒sn+1<sn  

Thus for N=10, n≥N⇒sn+1<sn.  

15 .

Let sn=1.3.5.⋯(2n−1)2.4.6.⋯(2n) for all n. Prove that {sn}∞n=1 is convergent and limn→∞sn≤12.  

Ans: Consider  

1<2 

⇒2n+1<2n+2  

⇒2n+12n+2<1  

⇒1.3.5.⋯(2n−1)(2n+1)2.4.6.⋯2n(2n+2)×2.4.6.⋯(2n)1.3.5.⋯(2n−1)<1  

⇒1.3.5.⋯(2n−1)(2n+1)2.4.6.⋯2n(2n+2)<1.3.5.⋯(2n−1)2.4.6.⋯(2n)  

⇒sn+1<sn  

This is true for all n∈I. Therefore {sn}∞n=1 is non-increasing. Also it is lower bounded by 0. So it is convergent. Finally,  

sn≤s1  

⇒sn≤12  

⇒limn→∞sn≤12  

16 .

Prove that the sequence {sn}∞n=1 is non-increasing where sn=2.4.6⋯(2n)1.3.5⋯(2n−1)1n2  

Ans: Consider  

snsn+1=2.4.6⋯(2n)1.3.5⋯(2n−1)×1.3.5⋯(2n−1)(2n+1)2.4.6⋯(2n)(2n+2)×(n+1)2n2  

=(2n+1)(n+1)2(2n+2)n2 

=(2n+1)(n2+2n+1)2n3+2n2  

=2n3+5n2+4n+12n3+2n2 

>1 

Thus  

snsn+1>1 

⇒sn>sn+1 

This is true for all n∈I. So {sn}∞n=1 is non-increasing.

 

17 .

If tn=1+11!+12!+⋯+1n! for all n, prove that the sequence {tn}∞n=1 is non-decreasing, bounded and hence convergent.  

Ans: A) {tn}∞n=1 is non -decreasing: Consider  

1(n+1)!≥0  

⇒tn+1(n+1)!≥tn  

⇒tn+1≥tn  

This holds for all n∈I. So {tn}∞n=1 is non-decreasing.  

B) {tn}∞n=1 is bounded: Clearly {tn}∞n=1 is lower bounded by 1. Consider  

n≥2  

⇒1.2.3…n≥2.2…2(n−1)terms  

⇒n!≥2n−1  

Thus  

n≥2⇒n!≥2n−1  

so that  

n>2⇒1n!≤12n−1  

Now,  

tn 

=1+11!+12!+13!+14!+⋯+1n! 

≤1+1+12+122+123+⋯+12n−1  

=1+1.(1−2−n)1−2−1  

=1+2(1−2−n)  

≤1+2  

=3 

So {tn}∞n=1 is upper bounded by 3.  

Thus {tn}∞n=1 is monotone and bounded. So it is convergent.  

18 .

Show that the sequence {(1+1n)n}∞n=1 is convergent.  

Ans: Consider  

sn  

=(1+1n)n  

=∑nk=0nCk1nk  

=∑nk=0n(n−1)⋯(n−(k−1))1.2⋯k1nk  

=∑nk=011.2.3.⋯k(1−1n)(1−2n)⋯(1−k−1n) 

≤∑nk=011.2.3.⋯k(1−1n+1)(1−2n+1)⋯(1−k−1n+1) 

≤∑n+1k=011.2.3.⋯k(1−1n+1)(1−2n+1)⋯(1−k−1n+1) 

=∑n+1k=0(n+1)⋯((n+1)−(k−1))1.⋯k1(n+1)k  

=∑n+1k=0(n+1)Ck1(n+1)k  

=sn+1 

Thus sn≤sn+1. Therefore  

{sn}∞n=1 is non-decreasing. …(I) 

Also  

sn 

=1+n.1n+n(n−1)1.2.1n2+⋯+n(n−1)⋯11.2⋯n1nn 

<1+1+11.2+11.2.3+⋯+11.2.⋯n  

<1+1+12+⋯+12n−1 

=1+1−12n1−12 

<1+11−12  

=3  

Thus sn<3 for all n∈I. Therefore  

{sn}∞n=1 is upper bounded by 3 …(II)  

From (I) and (II), {sn}∞n=1 is nondecreasing and upper bounded. Hence {sn}∞n=1 is convergent.

 

19 .

For any a,b∈R show that  

||a|−|b||≤|a−b|.  

Hence or otherwise prove that {|sn|}∞n=1 converges to |L| if {sn}∞n=1 converges to L.  

Ans:

|a|=|(a−b)+b|≤|a−b|+|b|⇒|a|−|b|≤|a−b| ...(I)  

and  

|b|=|(b−a)+b|≤|b−a|+|a|⇒|b|−|a|≤|b−a|⇒−(|a|−|b|)≤|a−b| ...(II)  

From (I) and (II), ||a|−|b||≤|a−b|. Next, Consider  

{sn}∞n=1 converges to L 

⇒ for every ϵ>0, there exists N∈I such that (n≥N⇒|sn−L|<ϵ)  

⇒ for every ϵ>0, there exists N∈I such that (n≥N⇒||sn|−|L||<ϵ)

(∵||sn|−|L||≤|sn−L|)

⇒{|sn|}∞n=1 converges to |L|  

20 .

If {sn}∞n=1 is a sequence of real numbers and if limn→∞s2n=limn→∞s2n−1=L then show that limn→∞sn=L  

Ans: Take ϵ>0.Since limn→∞s2n=L, there is N1∈I such that  

n>2N1⇒|s2n−L|<ϵ …(I)  

Similarly as limn→∞s2n−1=L, there is N2∈I such that  

n>2N2⇒|s2n−1−L|<ϵ …(II) 

Take N'=max{N1,N2}. Then from (I) and (II)  

n≥N'⇒∣∣s2n−L∣∣<ϵ and |s2n−1−L|<ϵ  

⇒∣∣s2N'−1−L∣∣<ϵ,|s2N'−L|<ϵ,∣∣s2N'+1−L∣∣<ϵ,∣∣s2N'+2−L∣∣<ϵ,…  

⇒|sN−L|<ϵ,|sN+1−L|<ϵ,|sN+2−L|<ϵ,|sN+3−L|<ϵ,… where N=2N'−1  

⇒(n≥N⇒|sn−L|<ϵ)  

This proves that limn→∞sn=L  

21 .

Give an example of a sequence {sn}∞n=1 of real numbers for which {|sn|}∞n=1 converges but {sn}∞n=1 does not.  

Ans: {sn}∞n=1={(−1)n}∞n=1. The sequence {sn}∞n=1 oscillates whereas {|sn|}∞n=1 converges to 1.  

22 .

If sequence {|sn|}∞n=1 converges to 0 then show that the sequence {sn}∞n=1 converges to 0.  

Ans:

{|sn|}∞n=1 converges to 0  

⇒ for every ϵ>0, there exists N∈I such that (n≥N⇒||sn|−0|<ϵ)  

⇒ for every ϵ>0, there exists N∈I such that (n≥N⇒|sn|<ϵ)  

⇒ for every ϵ>0, there exists N∈I such that (n≥N⇒|sn−0|<ϵ)  

⇒{sn}∞n=1 converges to 0  

23 .

Prove that the sequence {√n}∞n=1 diverges to infinity.  

Ans: Let M>0. By Archimedian property of real numbers, there is N∈I, such that

N>M2       …(I)

Consider  

n≥N 

⇒n>M2    (from (I))  

⇒√n>M  

Thus  

n≥N⇒√n>M  

This proves that {√n}∞n=1 diverges to infinity.  

24 .

Prove that the sequence {logn}∞n=1 diverges to infinity.  

Ans: Let M>0. By Archimedian property of real numbers, there is N∈I, such that

N>eM       …(I)

Consider  

n≥N 

⇒n>eM    (from (I))  

⇒logn>log(eM)    (∵f(x)=log(x) is increasing function)  

⇒logn>M  

Thus  

n≥N⇒logn>M  

This proves that {logn}∞n=1 diverges to infinity.  

25 .

Prove that the sequence {log1n}∞n=1 diverges to minus infinity.  

Ans: Let M>0. By Archimedian property of real numbers, there is N∈I, such that

N>eM       …(I)

Consider  

n≥N 

⇒n>eM    (from (I))  

⇒logn>log(eM)    (∵f(x)=log(x) is increasing function)  

⇒logn>M  

⇒−logn<−M 

⇒log1n<−M  

Thus  

n≥N⇒log1n<−M  

This proves that {log1n}∞n=1 diverges to minus infinity.  

26 .

Prove that the sequence {√n+1−√n}∞n=1 is convergent.  

Ans: limn→∞(√n+1−√n)  

=limn→∞(√n+1−√n√n+1+√n)(√n+1+√n)  

=limn→∞(n+1)−n√n+1+√n  

=limn→∞1√n+1+√n  

=0  

So the sequence {√n+1−√n}∞n=1 converges to 0.

 

27 .

Prove that if the sequence of real numbers {sn}∞n=1 diverges to infinity, then the sequence {−sn}∞n=1 diverges to minus infinity.  

Ans: Let M>0. Since {sn}∞n=1 diverges to infinity, there is N∈I such that  

n≥N⇒sn>M 

implying that  

n≥N⇒−sn<−M  

This proves that {−sn}∞n=1 diverges to minus infinity.  

28 .

Prove that the sequence {(−1)nsn}∞n=1 converges to 0 when the sequence {sn}∞n=1 converges to 0.  

Ans:

{sn}∞n=1 converges to 0  

⇒ for every ϵ>0, there is N∈I such that (n≥N⇒|sn−0|<ϵ)  

⇒ for every ϵ>0, there is N∈I such that (n≥N⇒|sn|<ϵ)  

⇒ for every ϵ>0, there is N∈I such that (n≥N⇒∣∣(−1)nsn∣∣<ϵ)  

⇒ for every ϵ>0, there is N∈I such that (n≥N⇒∣∣(−1)nsn−0∣∣<ϵ)  

⇒{(−1)nsn}∞n=1 converges to 0  

29 .

Prove that the sequence {(−1)nsn}∞n=1 oscillates when the sequence {sn}∞n=1 converges to a non-zero real number L.  

Ans: Take {tn}∞n=1={(−1)nsn}∞n=1. Note that limn→∞s2n=limn→∞s2n+1=limn→∞sn=L 

as {s2n}∞n=1 and {s2n+1}∞n=1 are subsequences of convergent sequence {sn}∞n=1. Now,  

limn→∞t2n=limn→∞((−1)2ns2n)=limn→∞s2n=limn→∞sn=L  

and  

limn→∞t2n+1=limn→∞((−1)2n+1s2n+1)=limn→∞−s2n+1=−limn→∞s2n+1=−limn→∞sn=−L  

So
limn→∞t2n=−limn→∞t2n+1  

implying that the sequence {tn}∞n=1={(−1)nsn}∞n=1 oscillates.  

30 .

Prove that the sequence {(−1)nsn}∞n=1 oscillates when the sequence {sn}∞n=1 diverges to infinity.  

Ans: Take {tn}∞n=1={(−1)nsn}∞n=1.Consider  

{t2n}∞n=1={(−1)2ns2n}∞n=1={s2n}∞n=1 diverges to infinity  

and  

{t2n+1}∞n=1={(−1)2n+1s2n+1}∞n=1={−s2n+1}∞n=1=−{s2n+1}∞n=1 diverges to minus infinity.  

It follows that the sequence {tn}∞n=1={(−1)nsn}∞n=1 oscillates.  

31 .

State True or False with justification. “If a sequence of positive numbers is not bounded then the sequence diverges to infinity.”  

Ans: False. For example the sequence 1,2,1,4,1,5,1,6,1,7,… is unbounded sequence of positive numbers that does not diverge to infinity. It is oscillating sequence.  

32 .

Give an example of a sequence {sn}∞n=1 which is unbounded but for which
limn→∞snn=0.  

Ans: Take {sn}∞n=1=1,√2,1,√3,1,√5…. Then {sn}∞n=1 is unbounded. Also  

limn→∞s2n−1n=limn→∞1n=0  

and  

limn→∞s2nn=limn→∞√nn=limn→∞1√n=0  

implying that limn→∞snn=0.  

33 .

(Sandwich Theorem) If {sn}∞n=1,{tn}∞n=1,{vn}∞n=1 are sequences of real number such that sn≤tn≤vn for all n∈I and limn→∞sn=limn→∞vn=L, prove that {vn}∞n=1 is convergent and limn→∞tn=L  

Ans: Let ϵ>0. Since limn→∞sn=limn→∞vn=L, there are N1,N2∈I such that  

n≥N1⇒|sn−L|<ϵ and n≥N2⇒|vn−L|<ϵ.  

Taking N=max{N1,N2} we obtain that  

n≥N⇒|sn−L|<ϵ and |vn−L|<ϵ.  

This implies that  

n≥N⇒L−ϵ<sn and vn<L+ϵ  

which further implies that  

n≥N⇒L−ϵ<tn and tn<L+ϵ    (∵sn≤tn≤vn) 

So  

n≥N⇒|tn−L|<ϵ  

This proves that limn→∞tn=L.  

34 .

If sn=knn! where k is positive integer, show that limn→∞sn=0. In particular show that limn→∞5nn!=0 and limn→∞10nn!=0.  

Ans: For n≥k, consider  

sn+1sn=k(n+1)(n+1)!×n!kn=kn+1≤1  

Thus  

n≥k⇒sn+1sn≤1  

⇒(n≥k⇒sn+1≤sn)  

⇒{sn}∞n=1 is nonincreasing  

Also {sn}∞n=1 is bounded below by 0. Therefore {sn}∞n=1 is convergent. Let limn→∞sn=L. Consider  

n≥k⇒0≤sn+1sn≤kn+1  

⇒(n≥k⇒0≤sn+1≤kn+1sn) 

⇒0≤limn→∞sn+1≤limn→∞(kn+1sn) 

⇒0≤L≤limn→∞kn+1limn→∞sn  

⇒0≤L≤0.L 

⇒0≤L≤0  

⇒L=0  

⇒limn→∞sn=limn→∞knn!=0  

In particular, taking k=5 and k=10, we get limn→∞5nn!=0 and limn→∞10nn!=0.  

35 .

Prove that if limn→∞snn=L≠0, then {sn}∞n=1 is unbounded.  

Ans: Suppose on contrary that {sn}∞n=1 is bounded. Then there is k>0 such that |sn|≤k for all n∈I. Consider  

|sn|≤k  

⇒−k≤sn≤k 

⇒−kn≤snn≤kn  

⇒limn→∞−kn≤limn→∞snn≤limn→∞kn  

⇒0≤limn→∞snn≤0 

⇒limn→∞snn=0  

This is a contradiction. Hence {sn}∞n=1 is not bounded.  

36 .

If {sn}∞n=1 is bounded sequence of real numbers and {tn}∞n=1 converges to 0 then show that the sequence {sntn}∞n=1 converges to 0.  

Ans: As {sn}∞n=1 is bounded, there is a constant k>0 such that |sn|≤k for all n∈I. Consider  

|sn|≤k  

⇒−k≤sn≤k 

⇒−ktn≤sntn≤ktn 

⇒limn→∞(−ktn)≤limn→∞(sntn)≤limn→∞(ktn) 

⇒−klimn→∞tn≤limn→∞(sntn)≤klimn→∞tn  

⇒0≤limn→∞(sntn)≤0  

⇒limn→∞(sntn)=0  

37 .

Let s1=√2 and let sn+1=√2√sn for n≥2. Prove that  

a) {sn}∞n=1 is upper bounded by √2.  

b) {sn}∞n=1 is non-decreasing.  

c) {sn}∞n=1 is convergent.  

d) limn→∞sn=2.  

Ans: a) Let  

P(n):sn≤√2  

As s1=√2≤2, P(1) is true. Let P(k) be true i.e. sk≤2. This implies that  

√sk≤√2  

⇒√2√sk≤√2√2  

⇒sk+1≤2  

⇒P(k+1) is true  

Thus P(k) is true implies P(k+1) is true. So by the principal of mathematical induction P(n) is true for all n∈I i.e. sn≤√2 for all n∈I.  

b) From a), sn≤√2 for all n∈I. This implies that  

√2≥sn for all n∈I  

⇒√2√sn≥sn for all n∈I  

⇒sn+1≥sn for all n∈I  

c) From a) and b), {sn}∞n=1 is non-decreasing and upper bounded. Hence {sn}∞n=1 is convergent.  

d) {sn+1}∞n=1 is a subsequence of {sn}∞n=1. Hence  

limn→∞sn+1=limn→∞sn=L (suppose)  

⇒limn→∞(√2√sn)=L  

⇒√2limn→∞sn=L  

⇒√2√L=L  

⇒√2=√L  

⇒2=L  

⇒L=√2  

⇒limn→∞sn=2  

38 .

Suppose s1>s2>0 and let sn+1=12(sn+sn−1) for all n≥2. Prove that  

a) s1,s3,s5,… is non-increasing  

b) s2,s4,s6,… is non-decreasing  

c) {sn}∞n=1 is convergent.  

Ans: Since s1>s2  

s3=12(s2+s1)<12(s1+s1)=s1 and  

s3=12(s1+s2)>12(s2+s2)=s2  

Thus  

s3<s1 and s3>s2  

This implies that  

s4=12(s3+s2)>12(s2+s2)=s2 and  

s4=12(s3+s2)<12(s3+s3)=s3 Thus

s4>s2 and s4<s3  

This implies that  

s5=12(s4+s3)<12(s3+s3)=s3 and  

s5=12(s4+s3)>12(s4+s4)=s4  

Thus  

s5<s3 and s5>s4  

This implies that  

s6=12(s5+s4)>12(s4+s4)=s4 and  

s6=12(s5+s4)<12(s5+s5)=s6  

Thus  

s6>s4 and s6<s5  

Continuing in this way (by induction) we get that  

s1>s3>s5>s7…>0 and s2<s4<s6<s8…<s1  

So {s2n−1}∞n=1 is non-increasing and bounded below by 0. Also {s2n}∞n=1 is nondecreasing and bounded above by s1. Therefore {s2n−1}∞n=1 and {s2n}∞n=1 are convergent. Let limn→∞s2n−1=L and limn→∞s2n=M. As s2n+2=12(s2n+1+s2n)  

limn→∞s2n+2=12(limn→∞s2n+1+limn→∞s2n)  

⇒L=12(M+L)  

⇒L=M  

⇒limn→∞s2n−1=limn→∞s2n  

⇒limn→∞sn=L  

⇒{sn}∞n=1 is convergent and converges to L  

39 .

Give an example of sequences {sn}∞n=1 and {tn}∞n=1 for which as n→∞,
a) sn→∞,tn→∞,sn+tn→∞  

b) sn→∞,tn→∞,sn−tn→100  

Ans: a) Take {sn}∞n=1={tn}∞n=1={n}∞n=1  

b) Take {sn}∞n=1={n+100}∞n=1 and {tn}∞n=1={n}∞n=1  

40 .

If {sn}∞n=1 is a divergent sequence of real numbers and c∈R,c≠0 then show that {csn}∞n=1 diverges.  

Ans: {csn}∞n=1 is convergent  

⇒limn→∞(csn) exists  

⇒1climn→∞(csn) exists  

⇒limn→∞(1ccsn) exists  

⇒limn→∞sn exists  

⇒{sn}∞n=1 is convergent  

Thus  

{csn}∞n=1 is convergent ⇒{sn}∞n=1 is convergent  

which is logically equivalent to  

{sn}∞n=1 is divergent ⇒{csn}∞n=1 is divergent  

41 .

Let {an}∞n=1 be a sequence of real numbers and
sn=a1+a2+⋯+an
tn=|a1|+|a2|+⋯+|an|
for each n. Prove that if {tn}∞n=1 is a Cauchy sequence then the sequence {sn}∞n=1 is also a Cauchy sequence.  

Ans: {tn}∞n=1 is a Cauchy sequence  

⇒ ∀ϵ>0,∃N∈I such that (n>m≥N⇒|tn−tm|<ϵ)  

⇒ ∀ϵ>0,∃N∈I such that (n>m≥N⇒||am|+|am+1|+⋯+|an||<ϵ)  

⇒ ∀ϵ>0,∃N∈I such that (n>m≥N⇒|am|+|am+1|+⋯+|an|<ϵ)  

⇒ ∀ϵ>0,∃N∈I such that (n>m≥N⇒|am+am+1+⋯+an|<ϵ)

(∵|a1+a2+⋯+an|≤|a1|+|a2|+⋯+|an| by triangle inequality)

⇒ ∀ϵ>0,∃N∈I such that (n>m≥N⇒|sn−sm|<ϵ)  

⇒{sn}∞n=1 is a Cauchy sequence
